facts.text: Appeal brought from judgment of Calcutta High Court dated March 10, 1964, in Income-tax Reference No. 116 of 1960

issues.text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether the High Court was right in holding that the bonus shares should have been valued at their face value and the loss of Rs. 35,000 on the valuation of the shares as such should have been companysidered in determining the applicability of section 23A.

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether the High Court was right in holding that the bonus shares should have been valued at their face value and the loss of Rs. 35,000 on the valuation of the shares as such should have been companysidered in determining the applicability of section 23A.

arguments.claim: Losses of earlier period Rs. 6,509, tax chargeable Rs. 17,829, subscribed capital Rs. 6,00,000; profits not adequate for section 23A

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner took the view that the losses of the earlier accounting period amounted to Rs. 6,509, the income-tax chargeable for the relevant assessment year amounted to Rs. 17,829 and the subscribed capital of the respondent amounted to Rs. 6,00,000. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner therefore held that the profits of the respondent cannot be held to be adequate to justify the application of the provisions of section 23A of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal agreed on losses and tax but rejected considering capital

arguments.claim: Application of section 23A(1) must be decided after recomputation of bonus shares value per principle in CIT v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question of application of section 23A(1) of the Act must be decided after recomputation of the value of the bonus share on the basis of the principle expressed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the argument put forward on behalf of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the argument put forward on behalf of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. it was held by this Court that when bonus shares are issued in respect of ordinary shares held in a company by an assessee, their real cost to the assessee cannot be taken to be nil or their face value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's submission that High Court's valuation of bonus shares at face value is impliedly overruled by precedent in CIT v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. correctly identifies the applicable law.

holdings.text: when bonus shares are issued in respect of ordinary shares held in a company by an assessee, their real cost to the assessee cannot be taken to be nil or their face value. The proper method of valuation is to spread the cost of the old shares over the old shares and the new issue viz., the bonus shares taken together if they rank pari passu, and if they do not, the price may have to be adjusted either in proportion of the face value they bear if there is no other circumstance to differentiate them or on equitable considerations based on the market price before and after issue.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. it was held by this Court that when bonus shares are issued in respect of ordinary shares held in a company by an assessee, their real cost to the assessee cannot be taken to be nil or their face value. The proper method of valuation is to spread the cost of the old shares over the old shares and the new issue  viz., the bonus shares  taken together if they rank pari passu,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent in CIT v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. prescribes the method for valuing bonus shares by spreading cost of original shares, rejecting nil or face value approaches used below.

holdings.text: It is manifest that the question of application of section 23A(1) of the Act must be decided after recomputation of the value of the bonus shares on the basis of the principle expressed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question of application of section 23A(1) of the Act must be decided after recomputation of the value of the bonus share on the basis of the principle expressed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct valuation of bonus shares per Dalmia precedent is required to properly assess past losses and thus determine if profits are adequate to attract s.23A(1).

holdings.text: For these reasons we allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court dated March 10, 1964, and direct that the High Court should rehear the reference keeping in view the principle laid down by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court dated March 10, 1964, and direct that the High Court should rehear the reference keeping in view the principle laid down by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court failed to apply correct bonus shares valuation principle from Dalmia, necessitating remand for fresh determination on s.23A applicability.
